importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ali Danial Hemani was indicted in 2023 on a charge of violating the federal guns-and-drugs law after the FBI found a 9mm pistol, 60 grams of marijuana, and 4.7 grams of cocaine at his family home.
A landmark Supreme Court decision in 2022 made it easier for Americans to carry handguns in public and established that gun prohibitions must have a historical basis to be constitutional.
The Iranian official Qasem Soleimani was killed in a US drone strike in 2020, which the Trump administration alleges links to Hemani’s travel to Iran.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 of the same federal law under scrutiny in the Hemani case and was later pardoned by President Joe Biden.
The Supreme Court agreed on October 20, 2025, to review whether the federal law banning certain drug users from possessing guns violates the Second Amendment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in the Hemani case in early 2026 and issue a decision by the end of June 2026.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, raising questions about whether such a ban violates the Second Amendment.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual citizen of the United States and Pakistan, who was indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm along with marijuana and cocaine, with the prosecution citing his habitual marijuana use.
A federal district court previously dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court decision that requires gun prohibitions to be historically grounded.
The conservative 5th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that habitual drug users, not just those under the influence at the time of arrest, should not be barred from firearms.
The Trump administration appealed that decision, arguing that habitual drug users with firearms present a unique societal danger, especially when impaired and in contact with police.
The government in its appeal also alleged that Hemani planned fraud linked to the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps and traveled to Iran to celebrate the death of Qasem Soleimani in 2020.

Hemani’s legal team countered that the historical basis for the law is weak and that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana, suggesting a significant overlap between legal marijuana users and firearm ownership.
Hunter Biden, son of President Joe Biden, was previously convicted under the same law in 2024 and pardoned by Biden during his final days in office, adding political context to the case.
The case is part of a broader trend of Supreme Court scrutiny of gun regulations, including a related case involving state-imposed gun bans on private property.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, centering on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistan citizen indicted in 2023 for marijuana and cocaine use and firearm possession. The case hinges on whether the law violates the Second Amendment, with the Trump administration arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially when impaired. A lower court previously dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court decision requiring gun prohibitions to have historical roots, and the 5th Circuit upheld that precedent. The Trump administration appealed, citing Hemani’s alleged ties to Iran and fraud-related activities, though Hemani’s legal team challenges the historical basis of the law, noting that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized marijuana. The case is further complicated by Hunter Biden’s prior conviction under the same law and subsequent pardon, adding political salience. The Supreme Court will likely hear arguments in early 2026 and issue a decision by the end of June 2026, potentially setting a major precedent on gun rights and drug use in the United States.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
